text: it's been three weeks since the girls
were abducted by the extremist group
Boko Haram so far the Nigerian
government has appeared powerless to
rescue them this has caused outrage on
the streets of the Nigerian capital
Abuja with protests growing everyday
and these feelings are being echoed
around the world the world does nothing
then they get away with this then we set
this horrible precedent so I think it's
extremely important that something is
done immediately to try to find these
girls to try to to bring them home and
God forbid we can't we have to still
bring these men to justice the u.s. is
now sending in a team to help this
organization Boko Haram has been one of
the worst regional or local terrorist
organizations in the world
we've long sought to work with Nigeria
on dealing with them and we're gonna do
everything we can to assist them in
recovering these young women looking at
what's on offer the u.s. operates a
basing neighbouring Nisha from there it
can send drones to fly over the dense
forests where the girls are thought to
be kept military personnel and forensic
experts are also expected to be deployed
the focus in Nigeria should have been on
the World Economic Forum which is
looking at regional growth but it's been
overshadowed by the painful news of the
abduction Nigeria has grown to become
Africa's largest economy and that's the
picture many here would want the world
to see but it's difficult to ignore the
ongoing insecurity which has caused
thousands of lives in recent years for
the families of the kidnapped girls the
agony continues there have been reports
of at least eight more girls taken by
Boko Haram a disturbing trend as the
list of the missing keeps growing tomi
Oladipo BBC News Abuja
